column13: Integrated farmers cooperative union was founded close to two years ago, according to the Ugandan statutes, it is the period required for registration to be effected, Myself together with some friends looked at the continued exploitation farmers were facing being fleeced by middlemen, and felt enough was enough. All profits were being taken away yet rice farming was a had task given the rudementary nature of equipment farmers were using. First thing was have farmers purchase their rice and look for market and sell at a better price, this would come in handy to solve the buffer stock impediment as well as having a stabilisation fund . We have grown to 3,000 farmers this mostly comprises of youth Uganda being the youngest nation in the world and women or young mothers. Our goals is not only to end at looking for better prices but to be able in future to use by products of these produce to do value addition chain, in production of feeds for animals, produce soft boards for construction, use rice husks to improve on the environment by producing energy for homes and industries , this will reduce on deforestation as fire word is the main source of energy for cooking. We feel this will spiral employment in 1. Animal husbandry agribusiness 2. Save the environment 3. Improve incomes to better living standards 4. Have affordable source of energy to power small scale cottages 5. Improve health and education standards since people can afford to pay And many others. Our conviction is cooperative is the way to go.
column14: Integrated farmers cooperative union is located in Eastern Uganda, Butaleja District, Himutu subcounty, Nalusaga Township

column12: Asero, Abeokuta, P.M.B. 2166, Sapon, Abeokuta, Ogun State, Nigeria
column13: In 1952, all Cooperative Associations in the old Western Region came together and formed an Apex body which was known as the Cooperative Union of Western Nigeria (CUWN). In 1976, as a result of political re-organization in Nigeria, the Western Region was divided into three states namely Oyo, Ogun, and Ondo States, thus the need for the newly created states to form and establish their own cooperative unions. This exercise gave birth to the Cooperative Union of Ogun State Limited in 1976 (COUSON), now Ogun State Cooperative Federation Limited (OGSCOFED). It was created to serve as an umbrella union for all registered cooperatives and unions in the state. It is devoted to the advancement of economic democracy through cooperation.
column14: OGSCOFED Limited performs these functions: 1. Auditing of books and records of all Cooperative organization in Ogun State, Nigeria. 2. Promotion and extension of Cooperative businesses. 3. Propaganda and Education 4. Public Relation 5. Service to Cooperative farmers 6. General welfare of the Cooperative Movement. 7. Sponsorship of new ventures. 8. Representation of Cooperative interests both internally and at International level etc.

column13: Ksouth huru huduma sacco is part of the kenya government initiative under national youth service that identified jobless youths in the city and provided them with environmental jobs such as cleaning the roads,unblocking trenches,garbage collection,sweeping etc.The wages earned by inidivuals were then pulled into one sacco thereby enabling the youths to engage in saving and borrowing of loans.The idea was to encourage the youths in our neighbourhood to engage in entrepreuniral activities,start business and watch them grow and be sustainable.We have several success stories from different youths who have set up successful business personally i have been able to set a container space business which involves renting our spaces on partioned shipping containers.I collect rents from the business stalls and i thank the government for providing the environment programme to the youths in my neighbourhood.Others have set up barbershops,saloon,clothing design shops etc

column12: 308 St. Olaf Avenue, Northfield, MN, 55057
column13: We collect compostable waste (organic waste like food scraps, paper products, etc.) from residents and businesses in Northfield and deliver them to a composting site where that waste is turned into soil. We also do education in schools, businesses, churches, and other establishments about what compost is and why its important.
column14: We have over 400 household subscribers to our business and currently 4 institutions/ business subscribers that we collect compost from on a weekly basis. We are successfully reducing the amount of waste traveling to the landfill in our county by providing this needed service to our community. We hope to grow into a collection service utilized by our whole town and neighboring towns, and to process the compost locally so that we can provide good soil to our farmers, gardeners, and landscapers in our area.
